questions.title: I
questions.article:
In certain solutions, beet cells undergo membrane disruption, causing the cells to release betacyanin (a red pigment). As membrane disruption increases, more, betacyanin is released. To determine the amount of betacyanin released, the amount of light absorbed (at a specific wavelength) by the solution is measured. As the concentration of betacyanin in the solution increases, the amount of light absorbed increases.

To determine the amount of light absorbed by a solution, light is directed through a sample of the solution onto a detector (see Figure 1).


By measuring the amount of light that hits the detector, the amount of light absorbed by the sample can be determined.

Experiment 1

For each of 9 trials, a student placed a beet section (2 cm x 2 cm x 1 cm) in 100 mL of water at a specific temperature for 10, 20, or 30 min. The student then removed a sample of the solution and determined its absorbance (see Table 1).


Experiment 2

Experiment 1 was repeated, except that in each trial an acetone/water solution was used instead of water and the temperature was kept constant at 25°C (see Table 2).


Experiment 3

Experiment 2 was repeated, except that in each trial a methanol/water solution was used instead of an acetone/water solution (see Table 3).


The student then determined the absorbance of water, of acetone, and of methanol. Each had an absorbance of 0.00.
questions.question: 1. Suppose that in Experiment 3 a beet section had been placed in a solution that was 40% methanol by volume for 20 min. The absorbance of the sample from the resulting solution would most likely have been closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 2. Based on the results of Experiment 2, which of the following additional trials would have resulted in an absorbance closest to 0.80 ?

questions.question: 3. The results of Experiment 1 are most consistent with which of the following conclusions about the effects of temperature on membrane disruption and absorbance? Higher temperatures resulted in:

choices.A: greater membrane disruption and higher absorbances.
choices.B: greater membrane disruption and lower absorbances.
choices.C: less membrane disruption and higher absorbances.
choices.D: less membrane disruption and lower absorbances.

questions.article:

Experiment 3

questions.question: 4. The student concluded that at a given concentration, acetone causes more membrane disruption than does methanol. Is this conclusion supported by the results of Experiments 2 and 3 ?

choices.A: No, because at each concentration tested, more betacyanin was released in the acetone solution than was released in the methanol solution.
choices.B: No, because at each concentration tested, less betacyanin was released in the acetone solution than was released in the methanol solution.
choices.C: Yes, because at each concentration tested, more betacyanin was released in the acetone solution than was released in the methanol solution.
choices.D: Yes, because at each concentration tested, less betacyanin was released in the acetone solution than was released in the methanol solution.

questions.question: 6. In Experiment 1, the student directly varied 2 independent variables and measured how these changes affected the value of the dependent variable. Which of the following lists an independent variable and the dependent variable in Experiment 1?

choices.A: Independent variable: absorbanceDependent variable: water concentration
choices.B: Independent variable: water concentration Dependent variable: methanol concentration
choices.C: Independent variable: methanol concentration Dependent variable: temperature
choices.D: Independent variable: temperature Dependent variable: absorbance

questions.title: II
questions.article:
How big a star looks at a given distance defines the star's angular size, (see Figure 1).


Table 1 gives of the Sun if it were observed from various distances. Table 2 gives of stars 8 light years away from Earth that have various diameters.

For a star to be seen as a disk through a telescope, the telescope's resolution, R, must be less than or equal to of the star. Table 3 shows R using yellow light for telescopes of various diameters. Table 4 gives R for a 10 m (diameter) telescope using light of different colors.
questions.question: 7. Based on Table 4, which of the following graphs best illustrates the relationship between R and the wavelength of light?

questions.question: 8. According to Table 3, at a given wavelength, as the diameter of a telescope increases, the smallest angular size that an object can have and still be seen as a disk through the telescope:

choices.D: varies, but with no general trend.

questions.question: 9. The Sun's diameter is 1.4 x 106 km. How does the Sun's diameter compare with the diameters of the 4 stars listed in Table 2 ? The Sun's diameter is:

choices.A: greater than the diameters of all 4 stars.
choices.B: less than the diameters of all 4 stars.
choices.C: the same as the diameter of the 4 stars.
choices.D: greater than the diameters of 2 of the stars and less than the diameters of the other 2 stars.

questions.question: 10. Table 1 gives the angular size of the Sun if it were observed from a distance of 8 light years. How would this angular size compare with the angular sizes of the 4 stars listed in Table 2 ? The Sun's angular size would be:

choices.A: greater than the angular sizes of all 4 stars.
choices.B: less than the angular sizes of all 4 stars.
choices.C: greater than the angular size of 1 of the stars and less than the angular sizes of 3 of the stars.
choices.D: the same as the angular size of the 4 stars.

questions.question: 11. A hypothetical yellow star at a given distance from Earth has a 3 of 2.0 x 10-2 arcsecond. Based on information in the passage, the star will be seen as a disk through Earth-based telescopes having which of the diameters listed in Table 3 ?

choices.D: Any of the diameters listed in Table 3

questions.title: III
questions.article:
A solid cylinder is mounted on frictionless bearings. A thin string of negligible mass is wrapped around the cylinder and pulled with a constant force, as shown in Figure 1.


The force results in a torque, τ, on the cylinder that causes the cylinder to spin. The angular acceleration, α, of the cylinder is the change of the cylinder's rotational speed over time.

Tables 1, 2, and 3 give τ and α for various cylinder masses, cylinder radii, and forces, respectively. Table 4 shows the rotational speed of a particular cylinder at different times.

(Note: All of the cylinders described in Tables 1-4 have the same length.)
questions.question: 12. Was the cylinder described in Table 4 accelerating (speeding up) or decelerating (slowing down) between 1.0 and 4.0 sec ?

choices.A: Accelerating, because the rotational speed was decreasing.
choices.B: Accelerating, because the rotational speed was increasing.
choices.C: Decelerating, because the rotational speed was decreasing.
choices.D: Decelerating, because the rotational speed was increasing.

questions.title: III
questions.article:
A solid cylinder is mounted on frictionless bearings. A thin string of negligible mass is wrapped around the cylinder and pulled with a constant force, as shown in Figure 1.


The force results in a torque, τ, on the cylinder that causes the cylinder to spin. The angular acceleration, α, of the cylinder is the change of the cylinder's rotational speed over time.

Tables 1, 2, and 3 give τ and α for various cylinder masses, cylinder radii, and forces, respectively. Table 4 shows the rotational speed of a particular cylinder at different times.

(Note: All of the cylinders described in Tables 1-4 have the same length.)
questions.question: 13. Based on Table 1, how is the torque t related to the force pulling the string and the radius of the cylinder?

choices.D: Torque equals radius divided by force.

questions.title: IV
questions.article:
Compost consists largely of organic matter that has been decomposed by bacteria that require oxygen. Compost is used as soil fertilizer. Two studies were done to examine the effect of compost use on the growth and yield of bean plants.

Study 1

Four different materials were selected for composting—offee grounds, pine needles, crushed eggshells, and alfalfa (a plant). Each material was placed in a separate container. A small amount of distilled water was added to each material. The 4 containers were then left in a warm location for about a week to allow the materials to decompose. During the week, the materials were stirred periodically and moistened with distilled water. The decomposition process was considered complete when the temperature at the center.of the material had risen to 40°C. For each type of compost, the pH, and the nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium contents were then determined (see Table 1).


Study 2

Each type of compost was added to 2 different amounts of a given soil to create mixtures that were either 20% compost or 50% compost. A ninth mixture contained 10% pine needles, 50% crushed eggshells, 20% alfalfa, and 20% soil. Each mixture was used to fill 5 pots. Ten bean seeds were planted in each pot. All pots received the same amount of light and distilled water. After 6 weeks, the number of mature bean plants growing in the pots and the number bf bean pods on each plant were counted for each mixture. The percent of seeds that produced mature bean plants for each mixture is shown in Table 2. Figure 1 shows, for those plants that produced bean pods, the average number of bean pods present on mature bean plants growing in each mixture.
questions.question: 17. Which of the following graphs best represents the nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium contents in the coffee-grounds compost, and the alfalfa compost?

questions.question: 19. It was hypothesized that the compost with the highest percent nitrogen, when added to soil, would produce mature bean plants from at least 75% of the planted bean seeds. Is this hypothesis supported by the results of Study 1 and Study 2?

choices.A: Yes; alfalfa had the highest percent nitrogen, and both alfalfa mixtures produced mature bean plants from at least 75% of the planted seeds.
choices.B: Yes; coffee grounds had the highest percent nitrogen, and both coffee-grounds mixtures produced mature bean plants from at least 75% of the planted seeds.
choices.C: No; alfalfa had the highest percent nitrogen, but neither alfalfa mixture produced mature bean plants from at least 75% of the planted seeds.
choices.D: No; coffee grounds had the highest percent nitrogen, but neither coffee-grounds mixture produced mature bean plants from at least 75% of the planted seeds.

questions.question: 20. Based on the description of Study 1, as organic matter decomposes, which of the following changes takes place?

choices.A: The phosphorus content of the material being composted decreases.
choices.B: The phosphorus content of the material being composted increases.
choices.C: The temperature of the material being composted decreases.
choices.D: The temperature of the material being composted increases.

choices.A: lower the pH of the materials.
choices.B: raise the pH of the materials.
choices.C: decrease the amount of oxygen in the materials.
choices.D: increase the amount of oxygen in the materials.

questions.question: 22. It is known that bean plants must receive some potassium from the surrounding material in order to grow to maturity. Based on the results bf Study 1, in Study 2, the mature bean plants in mixtures containing pine needles most likely obtained the required potassium from:

choices.C: both the pine needles and the soil.

questions.title: V
questions.article:
When DNA is heated to its melting temperature (Tm) it denatures (breaks apart) into 2 strands. When cooled, the strands can relink to form less stable DNA, indicated by a lower Tm(see Figure 1).


Figure 2 shows how the absorbance of light by a solution of DNA molecules, each initially composed of 2 completely linked strands, varied as it was heated and then cooled. When the DNA began to denature, the absorbance increased sharply. When the DNA began to renature, the absorbance decreased sharply.


Figure 3 shows how for heating varied for identical solutions of DNA previously exposed to UV light for different amounts of time.


Figures 1-3 adapted from Charles M. Lovett, Jr., Thomas N. Fitzgibbon, and Raymond Chang, "Effect of UV Irradiation on DNA as Studied by Its Thermal Denaturation." ©1989 by Division of Chemical Education, Inc., American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 23.  According to Figure 2, as the heated DNA solution was cooled from 90°C to 30°C, the absorbance:

choices.A: increased sharply, then leveled off, then decreased sharply.
choices.B: decreased sharply, then leveled off, then increased sharply.
choices.C: stayed level, then increased sharply, then began to level off.
choices.D: stayed level, then decreased sharply, then began to level off.

questions.title: V
questions.article:
When DNA is heated to its melting temperature (Tm) it denatures (breaks apart) into 2 strands. When cooled, the strands can relink to form less stable DNA, indicated by a lower Tm(see Figure 1).


Figure 2 shows how the absorbance of light by a solution of DNA molecules, each initially composed of 2 completely linked strands, varied as it was heated and then cooled. When the DNA began to denature, the absorbance increased sharply. When the DNA began to renature, the absorbance decreased sharply.


Figure 3 shows how for heating varied for identical solutions of DNA previously exposed to UV light for different amounts of time.


Figures 1-3 adapted from Charles M. Lovett, Jr., Thomas N. Fitzgibbon, and Raymond Chang, "Effect of UV Irradiation on DNA as Studied by Its Thermal Denaturation." ©1989 by Division of Chemical Education, Inc., American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 24. The following DNA molecules each consist of 2 identical strands. Based on Figure 1, a solution of which DNA would most likely have the lowest melting temperature?

questions.title: V
questions.article:
When DNA is heated to its melting temperature (Tm) it denatures (breaks apart) into 2 strands. When cooled, the strands can relink to form less stable DNA, indicated by a lower Tm(see Figure 1).


Figure 2 shows how the absorbance of light by a solution of DNA molecules, each initially composed of 2 completely linked strands, varied as it was heated and then cooled. When the DNA began to denature, the absorbance increased sharply. When the DNA began to renature, the absorbance decreased sharply.


Figure 3 shows how for heating varied for identical solutions of DNA previously exposed to UV light for different amounts of time.


Figures 1-3 adapted from Charles M. Lovett, Jr., Thomas N. Fitzgibbon, and Raymond Chang, "Effect of UV Irradiation on DNA as Studied by Its Thermal Denaturation." ©1989 by Division of Chemical Education, Inc., American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 25. A chemist claimed that for DNA molecules composed of 2 completely linked strands, the longer the DNA is exposed to UV light, the greater the number of links that are broken. Does Figure 3 support her claim?

choices.A: No; as exposure time increased, Tm only increased.
choices.B: No; as exposure time increased, Tm only decreased.
choices.C: Yes; as exposure time increased Tm only increased.
choices.D: Yes; as exposure time increased Tm only decreased.

questions.question: 26. A heating/cooling curve was determined for a new solution containing only completely linked, doublestranded DNA molecules. The Tm for heating this solution was found to be 10°C lower than the Tm for heating the solution represented in Figure 2. Which of the following best shows the heating/cooling curve of the new solution?

questions.question: 27. Based on Figure 1, how did the DNA molecules in the solution that was heated and cooled to produce Figure 2 compare with the DNA molecules in the solution prior to heating? Prior to heating, each DNA molecule was composed of:

choices.A: 2 completely linked strands only; after heating and cooling, each DNA molecule was composed of more than 2 linked strands.
choices.B: 2 completely linked strands only; after heating and cooling, only single strands of DNA remained.
choices.C: more than 2 linked strands; after heating and cooling, each DNA molecule was composed of 2 completely linked strands only.
choices.D: more than 2 linked strands; after heating and cooling, only single strands of DNA remained.

questions.title: VI
questions.article:
A student performed 4 computer simulation studies to model the change at a gene in a population. For each study, the following rules applied:

• The gene has 2 alleles (possible forms): A and a.

• Each organism has 2 copies of the gene.

• Thus, there are 3 possible genotypes (allele combinations for the gene): AA, Aa, and aa.

• Different genotypes may have different fitnesses (the relative number of alleles per individual a genotype contributes to the next generation).

• The fitnesses of Genotypes AA, Aa, and aa are represented by W(AA), W(Aa), and W(aa), respectively.

• p = the proportion of the alleles that are in Form A.

• Changes in p are due to differences in the fitnesses of the genotypes.

• Time is measured in generations.

Study 1

Three simulations were done. In each, W(AA) = W(Aa) > W(aa), and the initial p = 0.1. See Figure 1.


Study 2

Three simulations were done. In each, W(AA) = W(Aa) < W(aa), and the initial p = 0.9. See Figure 2.


Study 3

Five simulations were performed. In each, W(AA) = 0.8; W(Aa)= 1.0; and W(aa) = 0.6, and the initial p varied . See Figure 3.


Study 4

Five simulations were performed. In each, W(AA) = 0.625; W(Aa)= 0.5; and W(aa) = 1.0, and the initial p varied . See Figure 4.
questions.question: 28. In Study 4, the initial values of p were:

questions.title: VII
questions.article:
Students dissolved ammonium chloride (NH4CI) and silver cyanate (AgOCN) together in water. A solid, Product 1 (P1), formed and was isolated. Product 2 (P2) was then recovered from the water in the solution. Samples of the products had tjie properties listed below:

P1: Melting point > 400°C; hard and brittle; not soluble in water; not flammable; formula unknown

P2: Melting point =132°C; soft and nonbrittle; soluble in water; flammable; formula is CH4N2O

Two students discuss the identity of these products.

Student 1

NH4CI and AgOCN both are salts. Salts are composed of positively charged cations and negatively charged anions that hold together because they have opposite charges. When salts dissolve in water, they dissociate, or break apart, into anions and cations. When NH4CI and AgOCN are dissolved in water, the following occurs:

NH4CI + AgOCN → NH4+ + CI- + Ag+ + OCN-

The ions in solution then form new salts, silver chloride (AgCl) and ammonium cyanate (NH4OCN):

NH4+ + Cl- + Ag+ + OCN- → AgCl + NH4OCN

P1 is AgCl: AgCl is insoluble in water, and salts tend to be hard and brittle, to be nonflammable, and to have high melting points. P2 is NH4OCN, which is a salt composed of an.ammonium ion and a cyanate ion:

[NH4+][OCN-]

This sample of NH4OCN is soft and nonbrittle because it absorbed water from the air after it was isolated. This also caused the melting point to be lower than expected for a salt.

Student 2

P1 is AgCl, but P2 is not a salt. Ammonium ions do react with cyanate ions to form NH4OCN, but this compound is unstable. To isolate P2, the solution was heated at 70°C to remove the water. This caused the salt to rearrange and form a more stable covalent compound. In a covalent compound, the atoms are held together by bonds, not by their opposite charges. P2 is urea, which has the following structure:


Covalent compounds are generally not as brittle as salts and tend to have lower melting points. Also, covalent compounds are much more likely to be flammable than are salts. Urea is also a compound that is found in mammalian urine, so it must be soluble in water.
questions.question: 34. A compound is hygroscopic if it absorbs water from the air. According to Student 1's hypothesis, which of the following compounds is hygroscopic?

questions.question: 37. In arguing that urea is soluble in water, Student 2 makes which of the following assumptions?

choices.A: Mammalian urine is a water-based solution.
choices.B: Mammalian urine contains many dissolved salts.
choices.C: Urea dissociates when dissolved in water.
choices.D: Urea absorbs water from the atmosphere.

This caused the salt to rearrange and form a more stable covalent compound. In a covalent compound, the atoms are held together by bonds, not by their opposite charges. P2 is urea, which has the following structure:


Covalent compounds are generally not as brittle as salts and tend to have lower melting points. Also, covalent compounds are much more likely to be flammable than are salts. Urea is also a compound that is found in mammalian urine, so it must be soluble in water.
questions.question: 40. According to both Students 1 and 2, what solid was observed to form when the NH4CI and AgOCN were dissolved together in water?
